title: Early Sepsis Detection and Intervention
clinical_scenario: A 68-year-old patient with diabetes presents with subtle vital sign changes that could indicate early sepsis.

lime_rules: IF respiratory_rate > 20 AND temp > 37.5 THEN sepsis_risk = HIGH (weight: 0.31)
IF oxygen_sat < 95 AND age > 65 THEN deterioration_risk = HIGH (weight: 0.24)
explanation_provided.clinical_reasoning: Pattern suggests early inflammatory response with compensatory tachypnea. Combination of subtle vital sign changes in diabetic patient warrants immediate evaluation for infection source.

immediate_actions: Ordered stat complete blood count with differential
Blood cultures x2 from separate sites
Lactate level measurement
Urinalysis and culture
clinical_action_taken.outcome: Blood cultures confirmed E. coli bacteremia. Early antibiotic administration within 1 hour of flag prevented progression to septic shock.
clinical_action_taken.outcome_improvement: Patient avoided ICU admission through early intervention

lessons_learned: AI-driven early warning enabled intervention before traditional sepsis criteria were met
Explainable predictions helped clinician trust subtle warning signs
Feature importance aligned with clinical knowledge of sepsis presentation
explainability_value: High - Explanations convinced emergency physician to order comprehensive workup despite only subtle vital sign changes

title: Cardiac Event Risk Stratification
clinical_scenario: A 72-year-old patient post-MI with fluctuating vital signs requiring risk assessment for cardiac complications.

explanation_provided.attention_visualization: Model focusing heavily on heart rate patterns (head 0: 0.28), BP trends (head 2: 0.24), and historical cardiac events (head 5: 0.19)
explanation_provided.decision_explanation: Risk assessment based on combination of hemodynamic instability, compensatory mechanisms, and high-risk cardiac history suggesting potential for acute decompensation

immediate_actions: Transferred to cardiac telemetry unit
Cardiology consultation ordered
Echocardiogram scheduled
Adjusted diuretic and beta-blocker dosing
clinical_action_taken.outcome: Echo revealed declining ejection fraction (30%). Medication optimization and closer monitoring prevented heart failure exacerbation requiring ICU care.
clinical_action_taken.outcome_improvement: Proactive intervention prevented heart failure decompensation and potential need for mechanical support

lessons_learned: Attention weights highlighted vital sign patterns not immediately obvious to human observers
Integration of historical cardiac events improved risk prediction accuracy
Transparent risk scoring facilitated shared decision-making with cardiology team
explainability_value: Critical - Detailed feature contributions justified escalation of care level and specialist involvement

title: Post-Operative Respiratory Decline Prevention
clinical_scenario: A 55-year-old patient 24 hours post-abdominal surgery with early signs of respiratory compromise.

lime_rules: IF resp_rate > 22 AND obesity = TRUE AND post_op < 48hrs THEN respiratory_risk = HIGH (weight: 0.35)
IF oxygen_sat_trend = declining AND sleep_apnea = TRUE THEN intervention_needed = YES (weight: 0.28)
explanation_provided.clinical_reasoning: Combination of increased work of breathing, obesity-related restriction, and sleep apnea creates high risk for rapid deterioration. Early intervention critical.

immediate_actions: Initiated supplemental oxygen therapy
Ordered incentive spirometry with respiratory therapy
Increased monitoring frequency to every 2 hours
Arranged chest X-ray to rule out atelectasis/pneumonia
Adjusted pain management to optimize respiratory effort
clinical_action_taken.outcome: CXR showed bilateral lower lobe atelectasis. Aggressive pulmonary hygiene and oxygen support prevented need for re-intubation. Patient recovered without complications.
clinical_action_taken.outcome_improvement: Avoided potential ICU transfer and mechanical ventilation

lessons_learned: Feature interaction detection (obesity + sleep apnea + post-op) provided superior risk assessment
Trend analysis of oxygen saturation more valuable than single point measurement
Explainable predictions enabled early mobilization of respiratory therapy resources
explainability_value: High - Rule-based explanations were immediately actionable and aligned with respiratory care protocols

title: Elderly Patient Fall Risk and Delirium Prevention
clinical_scenario: An 82-year-old patient with multiple medications showing subtle cognitive changes and mobility concerns.

explanation_provided.decision_explanation: High risk profile due to confluence of delirium risk factors: advanced age, baseline dementia, polypharmacy, and acute illness. Combination significantly increases fall risk and adverse outcomes.
recommendations: Review and reduce medications where possible
Family presence encouraged for cognitive support

immediate_actions: Activated enhanced fall precautions protocol
Pharmacist medication reconciliation - reduced to 10 essential medications
Hourly rounding with reorientation
Moved to room closer to nursing station
Family education on delirium prevention strategies
clinical_action_taken.outcome: Patient remained oriented throughout hospitalization. No falls occurred. Medication reduction improved mental clarity and reduced confusion episodes.
clinical_action_taken.outcome_improvement: Prevented likely fall event and delirium episode, reducing length of stay by estimated 3-4 days

lessons_learned: AI identified polypharmacy as modifiable risk factor, prompting medication review
Multi-factor risk assessment provided comprehensive prevention strategy
Explainable predictions facilitated family engagement in prevention plan
explainability_value: Critical - Detailed risk factor breakdown enabled targeted interventions addressing specific modifiable factors

title: Chronic Disease Exacerbation in Complex Patient
clinical_scenario: A 64-year-old patient with multiple chronic conditions showing early signs of COPD exacerbation.

lime_rules: IF resp_rate > 24 AND oxygen_sat < 92 AND COPD = TRUE THEN exacerbation_severe = HIGH (weight: 0.42)
IF HF = TRUE AND COPD = TRUE AND CKD = TRUE THEN complication_risk = VERY_HIGH (weight: 0.38)
explanation_provided.attention_visualization: Model showing high attention to respiratory parameters (heads 0,2,4) and comorbidity interaction patterns (heads 1,5,7)
explanation_provided.clinical_reasoning: COPD-heart failure interaction creates risk spiral. Respiratory compromise may precipitate heart failure decompensation while fluid overload worsens gas exchange. Requires carefully balanced intervention.

immediate_actions: Pulmonology and cardiology co-consultation
Careful diuretic dosing with renal function monitoring
Bronchodilator optimization
Started antibiotics and corticosteroids for COPD exacerbation
Close monitoring of fluid status and oxygenation
Coordinated care plan addressing multiple conditions
clinical_action_taken.outcome: Successfully managed exacerbation while avoiding fluid overload. Careful attention to drug-disease and disease-disease interactions prevented cascade of complications. Patient discharged in stable condition with improved disease management plan.
clinical_action_taken.outcome_improvement: Prevented ICU admission and likely intubation through early coordinated multi-specialty intervention

lessons_learned: AI detection of comorbidity interactions enabled coordinated multi-specialty approach
Attention mechanism revealed complex disease interaction patterns
Transparent reasoning facilitated agreement between pulmonary and cardiac teams on treatment strategy
Trend analysis over 72 hours provided earlier warning than point-in-time assessment
explainability_value: Critical - Complex multi-system explanations were essential for coordinating care across specialties and preventing conflicting treatment approaches
